"Section 1. Findings and purpose." Congress finds that the tax treatment of section 529 college savings plans was changed in 2001 to exempt qualified distributions from taxation. This favorable treatment was made permanent in 2006, empowering middle-class families to save for college expenses. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 enabled middle-class families to use 529 college savings plans to save for rising college costs. There are 11.83 million 529 accounts open nationwide, totaling $244.5 billion in assets, with an average account size of $20,671. States sponsoring these plans ensure they are accessible to all families for college savings. The average 529 account size is $20,671. States with 529 college savings plans set minimum contributions as low as $25 per month to encourage participation. The President's proposed tax on 529 plans may discourage their use, leading to more student debt. The President's proposed tax on 529 college savings plans would discourage their use, leading to more student debt. The Act aims to strengthen and modernize 529 plans. The Act aims to strengthen and modernize 529 college savings plans to make them more consumer-friendly and responsive to students' needs. Computer technology and equipment are now considered qualified higher education expenses for Section 529 accounts. Computer technology and equipment, including computer or peripheral equipment, computer software, and Internet access, are now eligible expenses for Section 529 accounts if used primarily by the beneficiary during their enrollment at an eligible educational institution. Computer technology and equipment, including software, can be used by the beneficiary at an eligible educational institution. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. SEC. 3 eliminates distribution aggregation requirements in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment applies to distributions after December 31, 2014. SEC. 4 allows for the recontribution of refunded amounts. The amendment allows beneficiaries to recontribute refunded qualified higher education expenses to a qualified tuition program, exempting that portion from distribution rules. The amendment exempts recontributed refunded higher education expenses from distribution rules if done within 60 days after the refund, not exceeding the refunded amount. Effective after December 31, 2014. The amendment applies to refunds of qualified higher education expenses after December 31, 2014, with a transition rule for refunds received before the enactment of the Act. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on February 25, 2015, with a requirement for refunds to be issued within 60 days.
